awd_titl_txt: JST-NSF-RCN Joint International Workshop on Distributed Energy Management Systems, Tokyo, Japan, June 20-21, 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop proposal is to provide travel support for 20 US-based researchers to attend an international workshop. The workshop brings together researchers from U.S., Japan and Norway to share research outcomes and explore potential collaborations, and it focuses upon fundamental issues in reliable integration of distributed energy resources (DERs), resilient and efficient operation of electricity grid, and secure infrastructure systems.  The workshop covers such topics as monitoring, modeling, data analytics, learning, control and operation of transmission and distribution networks, especially those integrated with PV generation, wind generation, storage, demand responses, and other DERs. Research advances will be presented in relevant areas including but not limited to robust estimation, real-time optimization, distributed control, and defense mechanism for cyber and physical attacks. Electric vehicles, their interaction within microgrids, and interdependence of infrastructure systems will also be considered in the context of enabling smart and resilient communities. 
   
Unlike a traditional grid based on large-scale centralized generation remotely located from consumers, a modern grid has hierarchical information and control structures with a wide range of generation and demand responses resources, including renewables, energy storage and adjustable loads, as well as numerous intelligent electronic devices. Renewable sources are inherently intermittent and uncertain. To become reliable, resilient and secure, the grid must be capable of operating itself by incorporating distributed computing, communication and control, rapidly detecting and mitigating disturbances, robustly coordinating diverse generation sources and demand responses, dynamically optimizing grid operations and distributed resources, and effectively providing strong protection against physical and/or cyber attacks. U.S., Japan and Norway all have made significant strides in integrating DERs at high penetration levels, and the proposed workshop aims to have global impact by bringing together top researchers from the three countries, by showcase their extensive research and demonstration portfolios in grid modernization, and by identifying key topics of power systems reliability, security and resilience for further collaborative research. The two-day workshop will be held at Bellesalle Roppongi, Tokyo, Japan, June 20th-21st, 2019.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Workshop on Distributed Energy Management Systems, held in Tokyo from June 20?21, 2019, was a collaborative event among Japanese Science and Technology (JST, under its CREST program), US National Science Foundation (NSF), and the Research Council of Norway (RCN). The workshop follows a series of prior workshops aiming at exchanging information and establishing networks among researchers from these countries: 2013 workshop at Hawaii, 2015 workshop at Virginia, 2016 workshop at Heidelberg, 2017 workshop at Tokyo, and 2018 workshop at Mumbai.

The 2019 workshop at Tokyo attracted a total of over 150 participants including researchers from US, Germany, India, Italy, Norway, and Malaysia. The workshop grant supported 13 US faculty members to attend the workshop and present their research results. A total of 17 NSF program managers and US researchers attended the workshop.

The workshop includes the following sessions. In the opening session, Yoshimasa Goto, Executive Director of JST, gave opening remarks and CREST Research Supervisor, Prof. Masayuki Fujita at  Tokyo Institute of Technology, gave a status report of CREST program. Koshichi Nemoto, Director of the Central Research Institute of Electric Power Industry (ENIC), gave a keynote talk on the latest trends concerning the energy management system (EMS) on the demand side and the digitization of the electric power industry in Japan. This followed by an overall session where Radhakisan Baheti, program director of NSF, Svein Grandum, Counsellor, Science and Technology for Innovation Norway at the Norwegian Embassy in Japan, and Hiroshi Asano Deputy Director of SIP of the Cabinet Office, spoke on the latest EMS research trends in their own countries.

The workshop included six technical sessions where collaborative teams with members from different countries came together and presented their latest research outcomes. In addition, the workshop held two discussion sessions after presentation sessions and a poster session (with 50 presentations and one demonstration). Attending researchers and the representatives of their funding agencies, including NSF, expressed their hope that this international research community can be continued and further enhanced.
